title: Mystery: Where is Baden Bond?
text:
Use keywords to search content on this website Search Use keywords to search content on this website media_camera Members of missing toddler Baden Bond’s family speak to police on NSW north coast. Picture: 7 News Queensland Police call for help to find missing Woodridge boy Baden Bond Thomas Chamberlin, The Courier-Mail March 15, 2017 1:59pm 
DETECTIVES investigating the possible murder of a toddler who vanished a decade ago have appealed for the public to help in the case. media_camera Police began digging up the back yard at Wagawn Street, Woodridge last year looking for remains of the boy, who lived in the home with his family in 2007. Picture: Claudia Baxter 
Baden Bond, was last seen at his home at Woodridge, south of Brisbane, on March 27 in 2007. 
He was 22-months-old at the time but would be 12 if still alive. 
His family left Queensland and moved to New South Wales in August 2007. 
Police say they have found no trace of the boy. 
In January last year, a magistrate in a northern NSW town hearing a case involving the family asked of the whereabouts of the boy. 
The parents, who have a large number of children, told the magistrate he had gone to live with relatives in another part of the state. media_camera Detectives last year said it was possible the boy was living with relatives, had run away or had met with foul play. Picture: Claudia Baxter 
Repeated police attempts to verify the parents’ story failed to find any trace of the boy. 
Queensland police began digging up the back yard in Woodridge last year looking for remains of the boy, who lived in the home with his family in 2007. 
“Baden would be 12 by now and this is certainly a case we believe can be solved,” Homicide Squad Detective Inspector Damien Hansen said today. 
“We are seeking any information regarding his whereabouts. Any information, regardless of how relevant you think it might be, is important to us at this time.” 
Detectives last year said it was possible the boy was living with relatives or had run away. 
“Likewise, he could have been subjected to foul play. At this stage, we just don’t know,” one investigator said. 
Crime Stoppers: 1800 333 000
